title: 113_hr5143
content: The Act titled "Protection of Children Act of 2014" allows for the repatriation of unaccompanied alien children. The William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 is amended to include rules for unaccompanied alien children, removing the requirement for them to be from a contiguous country with the United States. The William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 is amended regarding unaccompanied alien children, removing certain clauses related to their treatment. The William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 is amended to allow the Secretary of State to negotiate agreements with any foreign country deemed appropriate. The William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 is amended to allow the Secretary of State to negotiate agreements with foreign countries. Amendments include changes to criteria for unaccompanied alien children and requirements for a hearing before an immigration judge within 14 days. The amendment includes changes to criteria for unaccompanied alien children, transferring custody to the Secretary of Health for those who do not meet the specified criteria. The amendment allows for the transfer of custody of unaccompanied alien children to the Secretary of Health and Human Services based on specified criteria. Before placing a child with an individual, the Secretary of Health and Human Services must provide the Secretary of Homeland Security with the individual's name, social security number, date of birth, and residence location where the child will be placed. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must provide the Secretary of Homeland Security with the immigration status, contact information, and other details of a child placed with an individual within 90 days of the Protection of Children Act of 2014. The Protection of Children Act of 2014 requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to investigate the immigration status of individuals with whom a child is placed and initiate removal proceedings if they are unlawfully present in the United States. The Protection of Children Act of 2014 mandates the initiation of removal proceedings for unauthorized alien children apprehended on or after June 15, 2012, under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Amendments include ensuring access to counsel for representation at no cost to the Government. SEC. 3. Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to allow special immigrant juvenile status for immigrants unable to reunite with either parent. SEC. 4. Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to remove jurisdiction of asylum applications.
